segments.key_quote: So different questions raised by Dharma are indicative of the different ways people suffer in Kali Yuga due to this age.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 20th verse of the 16th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining that it describes Dharma's lamentations to Mother Earth about the suffering in Kali Yuga.
segments.transcript: In this session we will be discussing one verse, the 20th verse of the 16th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, but since the purport is a big one, we will discuss this verse in two different sessions. So, this session we will be discussing part one, the first half of the purport of this verse, as Prabhupada explains this elaborately, it is a very important verse. So, the 20th verse: Padair Nyunam Shochasi Maikapadam Atmanam Vavrushalair Bhokshamanam Aaho Suradeen Hruta Yajna Bhaagaan Praja Uthasvin Maghavatyavarshati. Further, here is a description of the conditions in this Kali Yuga of people in general, in various ways they suffer, in so many ways. Okay. So, the meaning of this 20th verse is as follows: Dharma is speaking to Mother Earth, Dharma in the form of a bull is speaking, addressing Mother Earth in the form of a cow. So, what is Dharma telling the cow? I have lost my three legs. If you have lost your six legs, you are now standing on one leg only. Are you lamenting for my state of existence? Or, are you in great anxiety because henceforward the unlawful meat eaters will exploit you? Or, are you in a sorry plight because the demigods are now bereft of their share of sacrificial offerings because no sacrifices are being performed at present, or are you grieving for living beings because of their sufferings?

segments.key_quote: With the progress of the age of Kali, four things particularly namely the duration of life, mercy, the power of recollection and moral or religious principles will gradually diminish.
segments.summary: Srila Prabhupada's purport is introduced, focusing on the diminishing qualities of life, mercy, memory, and morality in Kali Yuga, referencing the 12th canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.

segments.key_quote: Chanting Hare Krishna is the best way of atoning for all sinful activities
segments.summary: The speaker describes the extreme degradation expected towards the end of Kali Yuga, focusing on the widespread killing of cows and the severe karmic consequences, and emphasizes chanting Hare Krishna and avoiding sinful activities as a means of atonement and salvation.
